column1:
Operator: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Nautilus Q1 FY 2016 Call. During the presentation, all participants will be in a listen-only mode. Afterwards we will conduct a question-and-answer session. [Operator instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded Monday, May 9, 2016. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Mills, Partner at ICR. Please go ahead.
John Mills: Great. Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to Nautilus’ first quarter 2016 conference call. Participants on the call from Nautilus are Bruce Cazenave, Chief Executive Officer, Sid Nayar, Chief Financial Officer, and Bill McMahon, Chief Operating Officer. Our earnings release was issued earlier today and may be downloaded from our website at nautilusinc.com, on the Investor Relations page. The earnings release includes a reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures mentioned in today’s call to the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Remarks from today’s conference call may include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws. These statements include statements concerning the Company’s current or future financial and operating trends, anticipated gross margin improvements, factors affecting our future operating results, including channel mix and segment margin, long-term growth and profitable targets, anticipated new product introductions, available supply of certain products, planned and anticipated results of new product and business development initiatives, and anticipated benefits and cost of the acquisition of Octane Fitness. Forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, and actual results may differ materially from those statements. For more information about these risks, please refer to our Annual and Quarterly Reports filed with the SEC, as well as the Safe Harbor statements in today’s press release. Nautilus undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements to reflect new information, events, or circumstances after they are made, or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events unless otherwise indicated. All information and comments regarding our operations results pertain to our continuing operation. And with that, it’s my pleasure to turn the call over to Bruce. Go ahead, Bruce.
Bruce Cazenave: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everyone and thank you for joining our call today. I’d like to start by providing a general overview of our first quarter results. And then we’ll turn it over to Sid Nayar to review our financial results in more detail. Bill McMahon will then provide details on each business segment as well as updates on product activity. I will then close with some summary remarks before we open up the call for questions. Following a strong year of performance in 2015, we are very pleased to report a solid start to 2016, which highlights continued execution of key initiatives across all aspects of our business as well as a broad-based growth in demand for both our cardio and strength products. In the first quarter total revenue grew by 26% which came from a healthy and complementary mix of both strong organic business growth and incremental new business from the Octane Fitness acquisition. The organic Retail business increased at over 20% while the Direct business increased 10% over the same period prior year. These are very satisfying growth numbers considering the recent events in the general of retail environment and the challenging comparison period we faced in the Direct business when revenues were up 46%. Improving gross margins is one of our key initiatives and I’m also very pleased to report that our efforts resulted an increases in both the Direct and Retail segments. In the first quarter of 2016. Because of the higher retail sales growth and resulting shift in channel mix gross margins on a consolidated basis declined by a 110 basis points to 54.9% as we expected. As mentioned in previous calls because of our very different operating expense structures between the two businesses. So long as each business segments margins are maintained or growing fluctuations in channel mix alone should not adversely impact overall bottom line profitability. Briefly looking at our bottom line. We continue to see positive improvement with a 10% increase in operating income and 15% increase in EBITDA from continuing operations. The underlying operating performance is even stronger, excluding certain non-cash purchase accounting entries relating to the recent acquisition of Octane Fitness, which Sid will comment on. We are very encouraged by the continued strong momentum and outlook in our organic businesses and remain very excited about the added opportunities that the Octane Fitness platform will provide. Our optimism and outlook is based on careful study of the capabilities inherent in the business and is reflected in the upward revisions to our targeted long range financial performance metrics, Sid will provide further details. With that I’d like to turn the call over to Sid to review our financials in more detail.
Sidharth Nayar: Thank you, Bruce. I’d like to review the details of our financial results for the first quarter of 2016. As a reminder this will be the first quarter where we include the financial results of Octane Fitness within our retail channel. Net sales for the first quarter of 2016 totaled $120.9 million, an increase of 25.7% as compared to the same quarter in the prior year. First quarter gross margins increased a 110 basis points in the Direct segment to 66.3% and we’re up 790 basis points in the Retail segment to 29.9% when compared to the same quarter last year. Retail margins include the impact of $0.7 million non-cash inventory step-up charge related to the Octane Fitness acquisition. Excluding this charge, Retail gross margins would have been 31.8%. On an overall basis total company gross margins for the first quarter of 2016 declined by a 110 basis points to 54.9% versus the same period prior year reflecting channel mix as a result of higher retail sales growth and the previously mentioned non-cash charge. Total operating expenses for the first quarter of 2016 as a percentage of net sales increased to 38.9% from 37.7% in the same period last year reflecting higher amortization expense related to the Octane Fitness acquisition as well as increased spending in product development partially offset by lower sales and marketing expense as a percentage of sales due to the change in channel mix. Sales and marketing expense for the first quarter of 2016 was $35.2 million or 29.1% of net sales as compared to $28.4 million or 29.5% net sales in the same period last year. The increased dollar amount primarily reflected higher media spending as well as the inclusion of expenses related to Octane Fitness. As previously stated improvement in sales and marketing as a percentage of sales relates to the shift in mix to a more retail weighted channel mix. General and administrative expenses were $8.2 million or 6.8% of net sales for the first quarter of 2016, which compares to $5.6 million or 5.8% of net sales in the same period last year. The increased dollar spending in G&A primarily reflects the addition of Octane Fitness as well as $0.8 million of higher amortization expense for intangible assets that was also related to the acquisition. Research and development cost in the first quarter of 2016 were $3.6 million or 3% of net sales compared to $2.3 million or 2.4% of net sales in the same period last year. The dollar increase reflects our continued investment in the engineering and design resources required to continue to innovate and broaden our product portfolio coupled with the addition of incremental product development resources related to the Octane Fitness acquisition. Operating income for the first quarter of 2016 increased to $19.3 million as compared to $17.6 million in the same quarter of last year. The increase reflects higher net sales and gross margins in both segments partially offset by higher acquisition related expenses of $1.5 million including the increased amortization expense of $0.8 million and the inventory step-up charge of $0.7 million. Operating margin for the first quarter of 2016 was 16% compared to $18.3 million for the same period last year. Excluding the $0.7 million non-cash inventory step-up charge referenced previously operating income for the first quarter of 2016 was $20 million a 13.7% increase over the same quarter in 2015. EBITDA from continuing operations in the first quarter of 2016 increased by 14.7% to $21.1 million, versus $18.4 million for the same quarter of the prior year. Income from continuing operations for the first quarter of 2016 was $11.6 million, or $0.37 per diluted share, as compared to $10.9 million, or $0.34 per diluted share, for the same period last year. Excluding the non-cash inventory step-up charge, income from continuing operations for the first quarter of 2016 was $12 million, or $0.38 per diluted share. The effective tax rate for the first quarter of 2016 was 38.3% compared to 38% in the same period last year. Total net income including discontinued operations for the first quarter of 2016 was $11.4 million, or $0.37 per diluted share, which includes a $0.1 million loss net of taxes from discontinued operations. This compares to the first quarter last year where we reported total net income including discontinued operations of $10.7 million, or $0.34 per diluted share, which included a loss from discontinued operations of $0.1 million net of taxes. Turning now to our segment results. Net sales in the Direct business totaled $81.2 million for the first quarter of 2016, an increase, 9.7% increase over the same quarter last year. Direct segment sales benefited from continued strong demand for our cardio products, primarily Max Trainer coupled with a slight uptick in strength product sales. Gross margin for the Direct business improved to 66.3% for the first quarter of 2016, compared to 65.2% in the same quarter last year. Gross margin improvement was primarily due to favorable product mix and continued leverage of our supply chain costs. Operating income for the first quarter of 2016 in our Direct business was $21.1 million compared to $19.6 million in the same quarter prior year. Operating income benefited from higher net sales and gross margins in the first quarter of 2016. Net sales in our Retail segment for the first quarter of 2016 were $38.8 million, an increase of 82.3% compared to $21.3 million in the first quarter of last year. The improvement in retail net sales reflects strong double-digit growth across both the cardio and strength components of the organic Retail business coupled with improved international sales year-over-year. While the addition of Octane Fitness also added incremental sales to the retail category. The dealer consumer portion within this segment did face some headwinds from slow retail traffic and inventory rebalancing relative to the prior year. Gross margins for the Retail business improved by 790 basis points to 29.9% in the first quarter of 2016 as compared to 22% for the prior period. Retail gross margins include the impact of the previously mentioned $0.7 million purchase price inventory step up charge related to the Octane Fitness acquisition. Excluding this charge, retail gross margins would have been 31.8% up 980 basis points versus prior year gross margin of 22%. Retail margin improvement can be attributed to improved product mix, better leveraging the supply chain cost as well as the inclusion of Octane Fitness products which generate higher gross margins. In the first quarter of 2016, operating income for the Retail business totaled $3.9 million as compared to $1.5 million in the same period of last year. The increase is attributable to the higher revenue and gross margins. Now turning to the consolidated balance sheet. Cash and investments totaled $72.8 million as of March 31, 2016 with $76 million of debt. This compares to $60.8 million in cash and debt of $80 million at December 31, 2015. Inventories were $36.8 million as of March 31, 2016 compared to $42.7 million at December 31, 2015 and $20 million at March 31, 2015. The decrease in inventory versus year end 2015 relates to the seasonality of the business, while the increase in inventory compared to March 31, 2015 primarily reflects the addition of Octane Fitness. Trade payables were $38.5 million as of March 31, 2016 compared to $61.7 million at the end of 2015. Capital expenditures totaled $0.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2016 which spending primarily on product tooling and IT assets. We anticipate full-year CapEx to be in the range of $7 to $8 million. Finally, I wanted to provide an update to our long-term operating metrics which we last provides approximately a year and a half ago. As a reminder these metrics are intended to reflect management’s assessment of the businesses annualized growth capability over three to five year horizon. We have left the revenue growth target unchanged at 10% to 12% per year. We continue to target operating income growth to exceed revenue growth. We have increased our targeted range for operating income as a percent of revenue from a range of 9% to 13% to a new range of 11% to 15%. We have added the range for EBITDA from continuing operations as a percent of revenue 13% to 17%. To better reflect the post-acquisition environment that includes higher amortization and interest expense. At this time, I would like to turn it over to Bill McMahon our Chief Operating Officer who will provide additional insights into our business and key products. Bill?
William McMahon: Thank you, Sid. Good afternoon, everyone. I’d like to provide additional background on our recent results and the overall position of our business. Starting with the Direct segment. We reported another quarter of strong revenue and operating income growth. We are pleased with his growth given the challenging year-over-year comparisons and which revenues increased 46% in Q1 of 2015 versus the same period in 2014. Direct segment sales primarily benefit from continued increase consumer demand for our cardio products, especially the Bowflex Max Trainer. In addition, we saw growth in strength sales due to improved performance in the home gyms. As Sid outline we reported strong direct channel operating income driven primarily by higher sales and improved gross profit margins coupled with leveraging operating expenses over higher sales. To get more details specifically on Max Trainer, sales of the Max Trainer product continued on a very strong growth trajectory in the first quarter. This trajectory continues to exceed our internal expectations and the historical performance of the direct channel products from the past. Sales and margins were further fueled by the introduction of the Max Trainer M7 model during Q1. M7 sales also exceeded our projections in terms of mix. And we’re currently working to ramp up M7 production volume to reduce the current lead time for a new purchase. Meanwhile TreadClimber sales have been assisted by the new TC100 and TC200 models we launched in Q4, 2015. However, sales are still on a post peak declining that. We attribute this today age of the product category now approaching 12 years and the continued strong trend in Max Trainer growth. We feel walking as a category as a large and profitable category and our product roadmap includes plans to address this trend in the long-term. Additionally, we continue to see a modest rebound in strength category performance in both Direct and Retail. Strength as a category remains one of our more promising areas for product development. And as such we’ve launched the Bowflex 560 dumbbell and direct catalog reaching consumers by mail this week and the product will go live online during Q2. Also our next major Direct product launch will be related to the strength category. But involve a new approach to whole body training. While we cannot disclose too much about it now we do currently anticipate this product being ready for market by early 2017. We plan to discuss this product further and demonstrate it and our new product showcase in New York City in late September. As we exit Q1 and move into our off season for direct. Our current credit media and consumer response trends remain very favorable. Based on this data we anticipate continued direct channel growth in revenue and profits throughout 2016. Now turning to our Retail segment. We’re very pleased to have delivered sales growth of 82% when compared to the first quarter of 2015. This improvement was primarily due to the addition of Octane sales to the channel. However, our original retail sale categories, which include sporting goods and online sales also delivered strong growth in revenue and profit. We are encouraged by recent product contributions from Octane Fitness, including the continued success of Zero Runner. Building on that success our team introduce the next edition to the Zero Runner family at the IHRSA and FIBO trade shows in Q1. The commercial Zero Runner ZR8000 was received very well and we were impressed by the interest by the interest that the product generated. ZR8000 will launch mid-year. Further we’re also seeing continued interest for the recently launched Octane Fitness XT-One cross trainer including the recent announcement that XT-One has been added to the range of premium Octane Fitness products at the David Lloyd Leisure clubs in the United Kingdom. This is one of several examples of how the acquisition of Octane Fitness is diversify our brand offerings and expanding our channel opportunities. As Bruce, mentioned we’re very pleased to report retail gross margins increased 790 basis points compared to the same quarter last year primarily due to the inclusion of Octane Fitness, which has accretive growth in operating margins while adding incremental categories to our Retail business. Excluding the impact of cost of sales of $0.7 million inventory step-up charge Sid described, retail gross margins would’ve been 31.8% for the first quarter of 2016, while Octane gross margins are and will continue to be accretive to the overall retail channel. It’s important to note that sporting goods in online segment also posted strong year-over-year improvement margin sustaining the relative gains we reported in Q4 2015. Octane sales in Q1 were impacted by some softness in the overall consumer specialty segment but this was partially offset by stronger performance in commercial products. Meanwhile sporting goods and online sales were strong across multiple categories including bike’s, treadmill and selectorized weights. Further international sales also grew strongly in Q1 2016 primarily driven by the addition of Octane Fitness sales and the continued deployment of Bowflex Max Trainer, which is now available in 15 countries. Turning to the retail brick-and-mortar space we’re closely following developments related to the sports authority, which is currently in reorganization proceedings. We previously fully reserved receiveables for that retailer in Q4 2015. Additionally last month the smaller retail chain Port Charlotte announced closer of all doors and we have reserved a small non-material amount for this partner in Q1. In the bigger picture our desire is to stay ahead of the changing trends in the retail landscape and adapt our strategies to win in the new environment. Our products are performing well with strong partners in the industry both online and in store. Our growth in Q1 despite the departure of two accounts from the segment is reflective of that strategy. We recently concluded the majority of our retail selling process for fall 2016. During that process we previewed Retail products that we plan to launch in the next year with buyers and merchandisers from all major accounts. Our products were well received and we plan to showcase that under our new product showcase event in New York City in late September. The assortment of products includes the Zero Runner ZR8000, a refreshed line of the highly successful Schwinn cardio series of bikes, elliptical machines and treadmills. And additional we will launch a new best line of Nautilus cardio products targeting incremental price points and preview a planned line of Bowflex branded ellipticals and treadmills targeted still another incremental price point. The addition of Octane gives us expanded sales reach and expertise in the specialty commercial markets and further helps in reaching International customers. This combined with our ongoing effort in sporting goods and online with a positive reception our new products has received provide optimism for continued growth in revenue and profitability for our retail channel in 2016. Before returning to Bruce for final comments I’d like to mention that integration efforts involving the Nautilus and Octane teams are well underway in the similar cultures in both organizations is paying off. Our approach to integration is to take the best of both businesses and unite around a path that delivers highest value for the capital invested. Given the strong talent on both teams the majority of that value will be in reaching incremental markets and price points faster. But we’ve already identified some supply chain cost opportunities in terms of freight and other areas where our combined entity has better negotiating power. Four months into working together, we could not be more pleased with the teamwork we are seeing. The talent and teamwork will be the formula that makes this partnership successful going forward. In short, we are well positioned to maintain a strong growth trajectory and we are encouraged by the progress of the integration of Octane Fitness with its ideal synergies into the Nautilus businesses. Looking forward, we remain focused on continuing diversification of our product portfolio, the expansion of our distribution channels and increasing our access to global market. And with that, I’d like to turn the call back over to Bruce for his final comments.
Bruce Cazenave: Thank you, Bill. I would like to make a few final comments before we open up the call for questions. 2016 is off to a strong start and progress is good as we are executing well to a plan that delivers on our goals of achieving another year of robust sales and profitability growth. We continue to push advancements in product innovation and design coupled with creative ways to expand our reach to both the home use and commercial use customer bases worldwide. Our brands resonate well with consumers in these varied markets and we intend to keep building on that. The financial health of our business remains strong and we are well positioned to continue to execute on strategies designed to maximize long-term shareholder value. Our strong cash flow and healthy balance sheet affords us investment opportunities to enhance value in multiple aspects of our Company. One of these as evidenced by the press release from earlier today, announcing an incremental $10 million stock buyback program. Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to thank our dedicated employees who work so hard to deliver desired results and how create a positive momentum that continues to make our Company even stronger. That concludes our prepared remarks. Now, I’d like to open up the call for questions. Operator?
Operator: Thank you. [Operator Instructions] And our first question is from the line of Lee Giordano with Sterne Agee. Please go ahead.
Lee Giordano: Thank you. Good evening everybody.
Bruce Cazenave: Hi, Lee.
William McMahon: Hi, Lee.
Lee Giordano: Just on the Retail segment first, can you talk about your latest efforts to get into the specialty and then how that’s progressing at this point in time? And then just secondly what are you seeing in terms of the softness in the consumer specialty segment, exactly what is occurring there and is that a new development, it’s not the first time we’re hearing that so just wondering if you can pinpoint what’s happening there? Thanks.
William McMahon: Hi, Lee. Bill here. We did see and we’ve noted others reported some softness in the specialty and it seem to be across the board in the category at least for this fitness season and multiple categories really products within that area and it seems to be a traffic at specialty issue. In terms of what our plans are for specialty, we believe that the way to win in that categories make a reason for people to come to the store and Octane had already embarked on this path with zero runner, a unique product to unique solution that people wanted to come and see. And we believe more of that will help the category in general at least as far as we’re concerned. So near-term this event happening doesn’t change your outlook for Octane which was otherwise strong in the Commercial segment, but it does make it say that as we approach the specialty channel, we need to continue to do the things we do well which has bring innovation and partner with those specialty retailers to help drive traffic, which I think we have some capability to do as well.
Bruce Cazenave: I think Lee I would add to Bill’s comments that we have the AD Pro Schwinn Airdyne bike that was targeted towards specialty and CrossFit germs and everything those that channel of distribution and Octane has picked up at the beginning of this quarter. They’ve now picked up responsibility for selling that product with all of their field sales organization deployed. And the feedback has been positive in that channel for that bike. So that’s a little bit of the early synergies that we talked about from a revenue standpoint.
Lee Giordano: Got it. Thanks. And then Sid just quickly the EBITDA guidance that you gave them long-term operating metrics like I missed exactly what that was? Can you repeat that please?
Sidharth Nayar: Sure. The EBITDA guidance was essentially 13% to 17% of revenue was a range.
Lee Giordano: Got it. Thank you very much.
Bruce Cazenave: Thank you, Lee.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question is from the line of Mark Schwartz with SunTrust. Please go ahead.
Mark Schwartz: Hey, guys, how are you?
Bruce Cazenave: Hey Mike.
Mark Schwartz: Just to continue on the Octane commentary a little further. Maybe just from a 30,000 can you just give us maybe what some of the early learning’s on that business are now that you’ve had it under - for about four or five months.
Bruce Cazenave: Yes, I think it’s kind of everything that we were hoping. I would say in terms of. We talked about culture fit, I think in Bill’s commentary. We talked about the innovation pipeline that Octane has and I think I guess one of the really neat surprises I guess we weren’t totally surprised is that our teams how well they’re coming together to jointly fill in product roadmaps, supply chain efficiencies and things like that there’s an excellent sharing going back and forth. And so we continue to be very optimistic about, the growth potential and possibilities in terms of operating performance that the business has at Octane.
Mark Schwartz: And then just a second question one of your competitors a few weeks back noted some caution around the large department store chain, but obviously is a large retailer of cardio and fitness equipment? Can just talk about just some of your credit exposure to different retailers out there and you talked about some of the sports specialty guys but just maybe a more holistic picture, please.
Sidharth Nayar: Sure. Mike this is Sid. We don’t give a breakout by individual customer, but what I can say is you know we just have one customer that represents over 10% overall sales. I would say it’s fairly broad-based brick and mortar/eCommerce platform base of customers that we have but I think fairly at the end of the day when you sort of look at - we continue to look at mitigating our risks by quite frankly looking at these customers very closely. And it sort of reflected in our experience with Sports Authority and Sports Chalet as you can see both those were relatively immaterial from our perspective.
Mark Schwartz: Okay thanks.
Bruce Cazenave: Yes, I’d only add to Sid’s comment say our optimism on our ability to grow. Sporting goods and online is also with that understanding of our desire to remain conservative where appropriate in regards to credit lines. Thanks Mike.
Operator: Our next question is from the line of Andrew Burns with D.A Davidson. Please go ahead.
Andrew Burns: Good afternoon and congrats on a great quarter.
Bruce Cazenave: Thanks Andrew.
Sidharth Nayar: Thank you, Andrew.
Andrew Burns: Nice to see an uptick in strength across the channels. Do you think that’s entirely product driven or is there some underlying change in fitness trends that you are tapping into their and potentially tapping into more so with your upcoming product launch? Thanks.
William McMahon: We definitely think Andrew, Bill again. Thank you for the compliments on the business results. We definitely think there’s a trend going on we think there’s some of merging trends and we definitely have either incorporated those things into Max which involve high intensity training is part of cardio. In our upcoming product will also incorporate some things that we believe are trends. In strength is related to that there is a general uptick and participation in resistance based training and incorporating that as part of a greater whole.
Andrew Burns: Great. Thanks for that. And I know you’re hesitant to give any sort of quarterly or segment growth guidance. As I look at the first quarter performance Direct facing incredibly difficult comparisons in an easing a bit and then you look at the retail side and great performance at the start of the year, very difficult end markets there. Is it reasonable to think that the segment growth rates would converge over the balance of the year?
Bruce Cazenave: I think and Sid can chime in here. But I think Andrew we as you said we’re pleased with the revenue growth that Direct delivered on top of that big comp. Retail remains we I’d say that we’re solidly in the double-digits for retail that’s excluding the incremental sales from Octane that will just be additive. But I would say that we’re still comfortable with the long range revenue growth parameters that Sid outlined in his commentary of that low double digit let’s say 10% to 12% I think we said. And I think that’s basically what we’re seeing is still early in the year but we feel like we have a line of sight to be able to deliver on our commitment as far as that long range operating metric this year and then beyond.
Andrew Burns: Okay, thanks. And in years past in the second quarter and third quarter there’s been times where you’ve invested in marketing spend to create awareness and drive regeneration head of the upcoming 4Q, 1Q sale season. I didn’t know if you could perhaps outline plans this season or just help us better understand what that would mean to the P&L here in the next couple of years.
Bruce Cazenave: Yes, I think Andrew the answer that is we don’t have a specific plan to intentionally inflate over our current ratios in terms of media spend, I will say our media spend will be higher year-over-year as we continue to invest in Max Trainer. So we would anticipate getting returns on that as Max becomes a more mature category at this point versus a launch category. And this year in the off-season we will be increasing spend but I did expect to see the good return on that.
Andrew Burns: Great, thanks. And one last one as you look at your approach to specialty there’s the Octane acquisition, AD Pro, I would imagine the Bowflex cardio would have the potential to in specialty. Clearly some effort going into that channel. I was hoping you could maybe characterize your view in terms of the health of that channel versus mainline sporting goods which clearly has hit a soft patch here?
Sidharth Nayar: I think specialty actually is healthy there are some other things contributing, we think to what’s happened recently there was a large specialty dealer who changed hands and ownership and there was some you know anytime that happens there’s usually some stepping in and some caution initially before the things get settled out over time. And I think the specialty dealers that exist today have been through that sort of thinning out that happened post-recession. And we believe the majority of those partners are certainly strong and they are looking for unique products to grow it. But it is going to be as we go forward they face the same challenges that the bricks-and-mortar folks do, which is that move to online sales, we see that trend shifting in our own Direct business where the shift to online sales in mobile especially is very strong. And I think we’re sort of uniquely situated compared to some of our competitors to be able to help those partners with ways to drive traffic and awareness of products that are in their store. Now we need to prove that out but we believe that that’s our secret to helping them. So those specialty guys who work with us going forward I think will be the beneficiaries of that multi-channel reach that we can bring to the table.
Bruce Cazenave: Yes. The other thing I would add Andrew is just to put to scale it for you, is to think about we talked a lot about specialty here but that’s really only one of a number of channels that Octane does business and in terms of our revenue stream and not to mention obviously our traditional bricks-and-mortar and dot com business and our direct- to-consumer. So I mean you have to scale it you know even if there is a little bit of perceived headwinds right now and I think they’re real in the early part of 2016 in specialty. You have to look at that that’s maybe $300 million, $400 million industry on the basis of a $10 billion worldwide industry. So you have to keep that in mind too. It’s still a value add that that channel provides, that we believe in and there’s a void out there that they fill very nicely. So it’s still very active for us and we think we can grow in that channel for sure, but it’s just - and important to keep in mind in terms of the scale of it relative to everything else to them.
Andrew Burns: Okay. Thank you. Good luck.
Bruce Cazenave: Thank you, Andrew. Any other questions operator?
Operator: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from the line of Frank Camma with Sidoti. Please go ahead.
Frank Camma: Good afternoon, guys.
Bruce Cazenave: Hi, Frank.
William McMahon: Hi, Frank.
Frank Camma: Hey, could you talk about the way you are marketing the new dumbbells. You mentioned that you’ve already won on a catalog basis they are going online, so it is mostly right now to former customers is that how you are going about it?
Bruce Cazenave: Our catalog goes out to incrementally and former counselor so it’s a little bit of everything there. Next it’ll be online on our own ecommerce sites and we’ll use digital marketing to promote it as well. And then we’ll grow from there. It’s not going to be a TV product, but at some point the new dumbbell technology will certainly be shared across both Direct and Retail.
Frank Camma: Okay. High. And on international, you mentioned you are at 15 countries now; can you just remind us like this time last year roughly how many countries you were?
Bruce Cazenave: I think, yes, Max Trainer. I think maybe one at this time last year.
William McMahon: Maybe two.
Frank Camma: More than two, all right. And last question from me is just on the R&D spend, it ticked up to 3% which - I think a long-time ago you mentioned that was kind of where you - the direction you were going in. Is that they - but that was pretty Octane and everything. Is that a level you think you’re comfortable with that 3% of revenue or is it - I mean is even tied to revenue, can you discuss that a little bit because obviously it’s up above the percentage and at an absolute basis.
Bruce Cazenave: Yes. And I think as you pointed out the Octane combination is a big part of that increase, but back to your point Frank, I think sort of short-term we are continue to invest heavily on the product development side, so we may even see a slight tick up about that 3% in 2016, but we do believe that’s where the gains at which in terms of new product and in terms of new innovations. So that will be from our perspective sort of that 3% is still very real and it could go up to something. We have plenty to do 30 basis points above that to in 2016.
Frank Camma: Okay, great. Thanks guys.
William McMahon: Thanks Frank.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question is from the line of Rommel Dionisio with Wunderlich Securities. Please go ahead.
Rommel Dionisio: Thanks, good afternoon.
William McMahon: Hi, Rommel.
Rommel Dionisio: Yes, thanks. Just a clarification question on the improved product mix that’s being key driver for gross purchased in retail channel. Is that - obviously Octane Fitness has higher gross margins, but is there also just within the organic Retail segment some positive gross margin from there. Clearly that’s price point differential or moving to constraints or something, if you could just provide more granularity on that please?
Sidharth Nayar: Sure, Rommel, yes, actually there has been substantial price point in the organic channel as well if you recall it was about 22% last year, but really a combination of product, it is some higher price points, it’s a change in product mix as well, clearly growth and the strength product category as well as channel related improvement in the selling Max Trainer. All of those are key drivers to improving and going up the organic Retail margins.
Bruce Cazenave: In international.
Sidharth Nayar: Right.
Rommel Dionisio: Okay. Also just thinking about more strategically the timing of certain new product launches, obviously the M7 and this new SelectTech are coming in after that sort of holiday [post new reservation period], is the thoughts strategically just to stagger the product launches to focus on specific product launches, as time goes on or it seems that you’re missing the key holiday season, obviously you’ll be there for next year but can you just maybe talk to that point to some degree.
Bruce Cazenave: Sure. Rommel, the direct product field, you’ll probably recall we did launch last fall the TC100 and TC200 refreshers in TreadClimber we do try to stagger our launches, so we’re not launching on top of each other especially if it’s a TV product like TreadClimber and/or Max. Hence the decision, Max as a category was doing quite well so a little bit of staggering away from the TreadClimber launch was in our opinion a good move, 560 since it’s not on TV and to be honest we’re a little late get it out, so we’re just trying to get it launched and move on. For Direct we have a lot of flexibility on when we can and decide to launch things. And direct peak period really is Q1 versus Q4. On retail there’s very fixed product launch dates that need to be hit and that has to do with the retailer’s needs. So the channels themselves are sort of independent in regards to product launch timing. But there is a math that to the way we approach it. And as you said it is about staggering the launches where possible in direct.
Rommel Dionisio: That’s very helpful. Thanks and congratulations on the quarter.
Sidharth Nayar: Thanks, Rommel.
Bruce Cazenave: Thank you, Rommel.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question is from the line of Steven Martin with Slater Capital Management. Please go ahead.
Steven Martin: Recognizing that this acquisition was not one designed to reduce a lot of redundant costs. You talk a little bit about. I know you alluded to it. You know what you’re seeing now that you’re sort of past the first quarter in terms of any redundancies or benefits from combined distribution sourcing, overseas, sales forces, et cetera?
William McMahon: Yes, Steven, it’s Bill here. We absolutely, see you know in terms of redundancy and people, we do not see any reductions coming in that area we wanted the talent from Octane to meld with our talent and that viewpoint has been proven factual and necessary going forward. So there is little to no overlap on our sales forces for example to specifically address that. In regards to supply chain, though, we went into this with the assumption of the products are very different price points, very different channels. So we’re already seen in terms of our logistics capability and overall supply chain that there will in fact the opportunities to save money across the board with the combined entity. And we anticipate some of that benefit will come perhaps sooner than we would have guessed. So there are definitely some positives in terms of savings and efficiencies. But I wouldn’t look for it in terms of headcount, we definitely want the talent we have on both teams.
Steven Martin: Gotcha. Specifically as it relates to the retail channel recognizing sports authority and sport [indiscernible] well, on is definitely disappearing and I think the assumption most people are making is that sports authority as an entity will disappear, but that many of the stores or volumes will be picked up by competitors. If I look at a sports authority door versus a Dick’s door versus an academy door, how would you categorize your exposure or your volume to each?
William McMahon: We don’t give away or disclose information related to various account sizes and we’ll say that we are well represented in Dick’s Sporting Goods and academy. However we would always like to earn our place in the more spaces the part of the reason that we’re able I think to continue to grow in retail overall despite let’s say some turmoil in the space at the moment. Is that we are a very small share from a starting point. And hence in some cases these challenges create openings for us because retailers are looking for answers. When our product performs well and is very well reviewed on line as our product is that it actually nowadays becomes more and more of a selling point to have the product on the floor. So for us we think opportunity. Now we have to be cautious and as Sid talked about earlier we need to work with the right partners at the right level of credit. But we believe that there’s opportunity in the retail space both online and bricks-and-mortar right now because of what’s going on. And we’re looking to have our strategy and products fit that need. Any other questions operator.
